content: The "FEGLI Living Benefits Act" allows for the option to receive 'living benefits' under Chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. The "FEGLI Living Benefits Act" allows terminally ill individuals covered by group life insurance to receive a lump-sum payment equal to the full amount of insurance if their life expectancy is 9 months or less. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for this process. The "FEGLI Living Benefits Act" allows terminally ill individuals covered by group life insurance to receive a lump-sum payment equal to the full amount of insurance if their life expectancy is 9 months or less. If a lump-sum payment is taken, insurance benefits may be affected based on the total benefits received. The designated portion of total benefits received as a lump-sum payment under the FEGLI Living Benefits Act will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000. Deductions and withholdings will be terminated or reduced accordingly. Optional benefits remain available to individuals who take a lump-sum payment. The Office's regulations for applying for benefits under the FEGLI Living Benefits Act require specific information and medical certification indicating a life expectancy of less than 9 months due to illness. When applying for benefits under the FEGLI Living Benefits Act, individuals may need to undergo a medical examination at the agency's request. Decisions on benefit applications, including medical prognosis, are not open to administrative review. Individuals can choose to receive only a portion of the total benefit amount in multiples of $1,000, with certain restrictions on who can make this choice. The FEGLI Living Benefits Act allows individuals to elect to receive 'living benefits' under certain conditions, with an irrevocable decision and limitations on the number of elections allowed. Regulations will address the application of benefits for individuals over 65 years of age. The FEGLI Living Benefits Act allows employees to elect group life insurance and accidental death coverage after 9 months from enactment. The Office of Personnel Management will set regulations for an 8-week open season for elections under chapter 87 of title 5. The Office will ensure employees and eligible individuals receive advance notification for making elections under this subsection. SEC. 4. FUNDING. SEC. 5. CONTINUATION OF HEALTH BENEFITS COVERAGE FOR INDIVIDUALS ENROLLED IN A PLAN ADMINISTERED BY THE OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY OR THE OFFICE OF THRIFT SUPERVISION. Enrollment in Chapter 89 Plan for administration of health benefits plan. Individuals enrolled in a health benefits plan administered by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency or the Office of Thrift Supervision before January 7, 1995, can continue coverage under an approved health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. This allows for enrollment in a new plan for coverage effective on and after January 8, 1995. Individuals entitled to continued coverage under a health benefits plan administered by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency or the Office of Thrift Supervision on January 7, 1995, can now enroll in an approved health benefits plan under section 8905a of title 5, United States Code. This allows for coverage effective on and after January 8, 1995, including unmarried dependent children. Individuals not meeting the requirements for being considered an unmarried dependent child under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code, can enroll in an approved health benefits plan for continued coverage effective on and after January 8, 1995. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Office of Thrift Supervision are required to transfer determined amounts to the Employees Health Benefits Fund. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with other offices, determines amounts to reimburse the Fund for providing benefits under this section. The Office administers the provisions for notice, open enrollment, and no lapse of health coverage for individuals enrolling in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5. The Office of Personnel Management determines reimbursement amounts for benefits under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code, and may establish regulations for implementation.
